item.summary: Oak instance fails with ConstraintViolationException on concurrent write

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
So what I did:

  • I used the test attached to this email and trigger it 3 times from my IDE.
  • the test uses a "database barrier" ( dbWriter.syncMongos(writersNumber, "syncOAK") ) and waits for all the java processes before starting to write

One thing I noted is, that the node name included in the error message contains a different cluster ID than the one of the actual cluster node. This indicates that at some point the validators get fed node states which were written by another cluster node.

There seems to be a problem with isolation between branches of the MongoMk in a cluster setup like this. Add the following test case to ConcurrencyTest.java, run three instances of it and it will quickly fail:

    @Test
    public void testMk() throws InterruptedException {
        dbWriter.initialCommit("syncOAK");
        // wait for all processes
        System.out.println("started cluster node:" + clusterNodeId);
        dbWriter.syncMongos(writersNumber, "syncOAK");

        String rev = mongoMK.branch(null);
        String nodeA = "nodeA" + clusterNodeId;
        rev = mongoMK.commit("/", "+\"" + nodeA + "\":{}", rev, "");

        for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
            String bi = "nodeB" + clusterNodeId + "(" + i + ")";
            rev = mongoMK.commit("/" + nodeA, "+\"" + bi + "\":{}", rev, "");
            String s = mongoMK.getNodes("/", rev, 0, 0, 100, null);
            if (s.contains("\":childNodeCount\":2")) {
                fail("Branch isolation failure (cluster node id = " + clusterNodeId + "): " + s);
            }
        }
    }

The failure looks something like this:

started cluster node:127

java.lang.AssertionError: Branch isolation failure (cluster node id = 127): {"nodeA127":{},"nodeA950":{},":childNodeCount":2}

The presence of nodeA950 in the private branch of cluster node 127 indicates, that the commits to the private branch of cluster node 950 somehow leak through.

The test setup is wrong. All MongoMK instances are started with the same id:

repo = new Jcr(new MongoMK((new MongoConnection("localhost", 27017,
		database)).getDB(), 1)).createRepository();

The test should rather use the generated clusterNodeId. With this change, the tests seems to run fine.
To simplify configuration, I guess the clusterNodeId should be automatically generated. I created OAK-731 to track this.
